entry.title: AFSUG & SAP: A New Era of Support ‚Äî Join Our Executive Series and Onsite Event in Cape Town
entry.content:
AFSUG & SAP: A New Era of Support ‚Äî Join Our Executive Series and Onsite Event in Cape Town

Together with AFSUG, the African SAP User Group, SAP‚Äôs Customer Support organization is launching a series of high-impact remote sessions ‚Äî all leading up to an exclusive onsite event in Cape Town in March 2026. This program gives customers a unique opportunity to learn directly from SAP executives and experts, discover the future of support, and experience how AI, automation, and preventative practices are reshaping SAP‚Äôs entire support landscape. Whether you want to understand SAP‚Äôs proactive support strategy, get hands-on with the latest digital experiences, or explore agentic AI in real customer scenarios ‚Äî this series is built for you.

Why This Series Matters

SAP Support has evolved far beyond ‚Äúbreak/fix.‚Äù Today, it is:

  • A strategic advantage, not an insurance policy
    SAP customers choose us because we help them run better, scale smarter, and stay ahead.
  • Preventive and predictive by design
    Programs like Black Friday / Cyber Monday Readiness demonstrate how SAP reduces risk before issues arise.
  • AI-powered, human-backed
    Agentic AI, prescriptive guidance, and intelligent digital entry points give customers immediate access to insights and the right expertise.
  • Embedded across the entire lifecycle
    Support is now a built-in value multiplier ‚Äî from onboarding to transformation to continuous optimization.
  • Customer outcomes at the center
    Stability, performance, resilience, and continuous improvement aren‚Äôt extras ‚Äî they‚Äôre expectations.
  • A blueprint for operationalizing AI
    SAP Customer Support is the frontrunner in adopting agentic AI inside SAP ‚Äî and showing customers how to scale AI safely and practically in their own environments.

Join our experts as they unpack these themes in four remote sessions ‚Äî each one providing unique insights and previews of what awaits at the onsite event in Cape Town.

Remote Session Series

1. November 27, 2025 ‚Äî 3‚Äì4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

From Reactive to Proactive: How SAP‚Äôs Support Strategy & Agentic AI Are Reshaping the Future

Speaker: Stefan Steinle, EVP & Head of Customer Support & Cloud Lifecycle Management, SAP SE

Support is shifting from reactive problem-solving to strategic enablement. Stefan Steinle will walk attendees through SAP‚Äôs future support strategy ‚Äî one that is predictive, preventative, and deeply infused with agentic AI.

You‚Äôll learn:

  • How SAP is moving toward proactive and preventative support models
  • How agentic AI analyzes telemetry, detects risks, and takes safe autonomous action
  • How disciplines from BF/CM Readiness are expanding into daily operations
  • A live demo on proactive support identifying ‚ÄúGo-Live endangered‚Äù situations
  • A first look at what awaits at the Cape Town onsite event ‚Äî including Support Accreditation

üëâRegister now to secure your place.

2. December 11, 2025 ‚Äî 3‚Äì4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

Reinventing Support ‚Äì Self-Services, Real-Time Assistance & the Power of AI

Speaker: Mohammed Ajouz, SVP & Global Head of Technical Support, SAP Americas

Traditional support is being reinvented. Mohammed Ajouz will showcase how SAP delivers intelligent, connected, and customer-centric services.

In this session, you‚Äôll explore:

  • Smarter, always-available self-services
  • Live channels for real-time engagement
  • Agentic AI that supports ‚Äî and acts ‚Äî on your behalf
  • How AI and LLMs transform knowledge, case resolution, and insights

You‚Äôll also get a preview of the onsite workshops and simulations ‚Äî and how to earn the SAP Support Accreditation Certificate in Cape Town.

üëâRegister now to secure your place.

3. January 21, 2026 ‚Äî 3‚Äì4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

SAP Cloud ALM as Your Transformation Execution Platform

Speaker: S√∂ren Ruder, SVP & CPO, Global Head of Customer Experience & Solutions, SAP SE

Transformation succeeds when tools work together ‚Äî not in silos. This session shows how SAP Cloud ALM unifies processes, architecture, testing, and operations into a single AI-infused orchestration layer.

Learn how Cloud ALM:

  • Aligns Signavio processes directly with project scope
  • Synchronizes landscape models from SAP LeanIX
  • Coordinates manual and automated testing
  • Orchestrates ABAP and non-ABAP change processes
  • Uses intelligent event processing to reduce noise and automate remediation
  • Delivers real-time dashboards with embedded analytics

S√∂ren Ruder will also preview deep-dive workshops happening onsite in Cape Town.

üëâRegister now for the January session.

4. February 26, 2026 ‚Äî 3‚Äì4 PM CET / 4-5 PM SAST

Intelligent Front Door Thinking

Speaker: Michelle Lewis-Miller, Head of SAP Support Digital Experience & Voice of Customer, SAP SE

Every customer journey starts with a digital front door ‚Äî and SAP is reinventing it.

This session includes:

  • Live demos of SAP for Me, the Get Support App, and the SAP Support Portal
  • Insights into personalization, streamlined access, mobility, and new navigation patterns
  • The debut of the SAP Support Accreditation Program

This is your best opportunity to get ready for certification onsite in Cape Town.

üëâRegister now for the February session.

üåçMarch 26, 2026 ‚Äî Onsite in Cape Town, South Africa

AFSUG & SAP: From Insights to Impact

All remote sessions lead to this highly interactive onsite event ‚Äî bringing together SAP executives, experts, and customers for a full day of hands-on learning, networking, and certification.

Onsite Highlights:

  • Keynote by Stefan Steinle: The Future of Support ‚Äî Intelligent, Preventive, and Built for the Cloud Era

  • Multiple expert deep-dives on:

    • SAP for Me & Built-In Support
    • Self-Services, Live Channels & AI
    • Preventive Support & Agentic AI
    • SAP Cloud ALM and the Integrated Toolchain
  • Meet-the-Expert stations
  • Direct networking with SAP executives
  • SAP Support Accreditation ‚Äî completed onsite with printed certificate

This is the moment where everything comes together ‚Äî strategy, demos, hands-on labs, customer stories, and the opportunity to connect directly with the people shaping the future of support.

üëâRegistration opens soon ‚Äî reserve the date now.

Join Us for the Full Journey

These remote sessions and the Cape Town onsite event offer an exceptional opportunity to:

  • Learn from SAP‚Äôs top executives
  • See agentic AI in action
  • Strengthen your SAP expertise
  • Network with industry peers
  • Earn your official SAP Support Accreditation

Don‚Äôt miss your chance to be part of this evolution.
Register for the sessions, mark your calendar for Cape Town ‚Äî and join us as we shape the next era of SAP Support together.

entry.title: Common configuration issues: Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Let's look at the common issues that we may have while setting up Joule with SuccessFactors:

  1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing
  2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed
  3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA
  4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud
  5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working
  6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

==================================================================================

So let us take a look at the issue and how to fix them:

1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing

While running the booster, we got the error message:

‚ÄúSome of the entitlements are not available in the selected subaccount <XXXX>. Please either add them or select a subaccount with different provider or region.‚Äù

Fix: 

Go to BTP Global Account -> Entity Assignments.

Check if Joule and SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition service are entitled to the subaccount.

If Joule is not available in BTP Global Account -> Procure Joule

 

2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed

While running the Joule booster, we got the error message:

 

Fix: Please follow the KBA to setup accordingly: 

3539985 - Synchronization failed between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services when using booster for Joule setup

 

3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA

While running the booster, we got the error message:

Cause: S/4HANA system is not registered with BTP global account.

Fix: Double check the steps ‚ÄúRegister SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in BTP Global Account‚Äù in the mission.

 

4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud

There are several reasons might cause this issue, please follow below to check:

4.1 Double check the step ‚ÄúUpdate Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud‚Äù in mission

Follow the last step to paste the URL of your Joule application into the Trusted Content text box and click Save.

4. 2  Try opening the system in an Incognito window to rule out browser cache issues.
If Joule appears there, clear your browser cache and cookies before accessing it again in normal mode.

4.3 When logging int S/4HANA Public Cloud, check the domain of Cloud Identity Services that is used during login (e.g. ending with ondemand.com or cloud.sap) => in BTP Cockpit -> Joule Subaccount -> Trust Configuration -> Select the Cloud Identity Services used for application logon -> check if the ‚ÄúDomain‚Äù is set to the same domain used in S4.

4.4 Check in Cloud Identity Services if the hosting application (S/4Public Cloud) and Joule application are configured in exact same way (IDP/Conditional authentication)

 

5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working

5.1 Cause: CDM content not synchronised

Fix: In the Channel Manager of Build Workzone, please click on "Report" to check how many apps / roles were actually synchronised.

5. 2 Cause: User lacking role assignments.

Fix:  Check whether the logged in user actually have the required groups assigned.

Check the sample prompts and corresponding roles here.

5. 3 Double check below steps in the mission

  • Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone
  • Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

Cause: In rare cases the automated integration between Joule and S/4HANA might fail.

Fix: Check if the CN name used in Destination S4HANA_PUB_SSO fits to the CN name maintained in S/4HANA.
In case of mismatch open an incident with CA-JOULE

CN name in above screenshot need to match between BTP Destination and S/4 Communication System (Signing Certificate Issuer in below screenshot).

 

If the issue still persists or any other issues not listed here, open a ticket under component CA-JOULE.

 

Cheers, 

Happy Learning

SAP Business AI RIG team

entry.title: Adoption Isn‚Äôt a Phase, It‚Äôs a Relationship
entry.content:
If you know me, you know I love an analogy. It‚Äôs always helpful to make new information make sense by likening it to something we already understand.

In my role here at SAP, I talk about adoption a lot. It‚Äôs a point that I (and my wonderful team, Solution Value Advisory) really push with our customers, who sometimes think of adoption as a step in the overall process, something you do after go-live.  So, my analogy for today is to look at adoption like a relationship, because it‚Äôs never just about the software, but about the people and how they interact with the system and each other.

It‚Äôs not much of a stretch, really. At the start, it‚Äôs a mix of excitement, a little confusion, and commitment that comes with bringing something new into your life, and hoping it thrives, grows, and has the support of people around you.


The honeymoon stage
 In my last role several years back, I worked on Ariba solution implementations. Being on a shared services team, I got to stick my hands into a lot of different customers‚Äô Ariba deployments. It felt great, for the customer and for me, to reach what felt like a finish line: go-live. That point of the new solution(s) going live after months of setup and testing. The vibes were always good - everyone was hopeful, users explored the system, performed tests. Teams got trained. There was that spark of possibility, that sense of this time, things will be different.

But just like any new relationship, the shine fades if the day-to-day connection isn‚Äôt nurtured. Old habits creep back in, shortcuts resurface. And, before long, that beautiful new tool starts gathering dust.  Remember, adoption doesn‚Äôt end at go-live, that‚Äôs when it begins.


Relationships thrive on consistency, and so do systems
Healthy adoption looks a lot like a healthy partnership: steady, intentional, and full of small moments that build trust.

It‚Äôs when someone logs in and sees that their preferences were remembered. It‚Äôs when data syncs across systems, so people stop fighting with spreadsheets and endless back-and-forth email. It‚Äôs when users realize the tool makes their jobs easier, not harder. It keeps the relationship alive.

But breakdowns don‚Äôt usually happen with a bang, but a fizzle. Users don‚Äôt revolt, they quietly disengage. They skip the process ‚Äújust this once.‚Äù Then they stop trusting the data, because the process is getting skipped and they can‚Äôt find what they were looking for. And now something that was originally set up to create efficiency is now only causing frustration, and becomes a pain in the‚Ä¶well, you know. üòä

In my work with customers, I see this all the time.  I work a lot with customers on their supplier management processes especially, and I see a lot of this disengagement when it comes to onboarding. Tools like SAP Cloud Identity Services and SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle & Performance (SLP) can be super powerful, but they depend on trusted data and consistency. If people don‚Äôt understand why something matters, they won‚Äôt invest in making it work.

The love language of AI is good data
Now we‚Äôre entering a new chapter, one where AI tools like SAP Joule are ready to help make our jobs easier. But even Joule, which might seem like magic when you see it presented, needs a foundation of trust. This has been my main message of the year - reminding people that AI doesn‚Äôt make magic out of thin air, rather it builds on what we give it. If data is messy, disconnected, or if established processes are underused, Joule‚Äôs insights will be, too.

(Pausing here for a shoutout to anyone who was at the Customer Success Day in NYC earlier this year where I did a whole session to essentially say, ‚ÄúGarbage in, garbage out‚Äù. The highlight, at least to me, was my AI-generated Ariba song parody of Naughty by Nature‚Äôs O.P.P.  Who‚Äôs down with SLP? Yeah you know me!)

But back to my relationship analogy, think of it this way: if you never talk to your partner, you can‚Äôt expect them to finish your sentences. Joule works the same way. The relationship only deepens when we communicate through connected, clean, and well-adopted systems. 


Adoption is ongoing care.
As I said before, adoption isn‚Äôt a task. We don‚Äôt ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù adoption. We maintain it. We check in with our users, we update them on changes, and we listen when something isn‚Äôt working and adjust before resentment sets in.  The most successful customers I see are those who treat adoption as a living process. Not just implementing technology, but inviting it into their company culture. When adoption is healthy, everything else (innovation, automation, AI, etc.) starts to flow naturally.  But just like any great relationship, it takes attention, empathy, and patience.


I encourage you all to stay in tune with our roadmap, as there‚Äôs a lot of exciting stuff to come in 2026 when it comes to AI in SAP. But as you read up on that and start to think how cool it will be and how much time it will save to have all of those new capabilities, remember that now is the time to build the foundation for that new relationship. 

If you have any doubts about how well your company is adopting your solutions and how you‚Äôre doing on usage in comparison to other customers, do reach out to your CSM who can either help, or can pull in the right people to have that conversation. Sometimes that person is me, so say hi and maybe I'll share my library of Ariba song parodies.

entry.title: Everything My Mom Taught Me about Change Management for AI in Procurement
entry.content:
A Story about Change Done Right

Growing up, our dinner table conversations were a mix of stories about our day. My dad, a computer programmer for a large tech company, would talk about coding languages and mainframes, while my mom would share stories about her accounting role at a regional office for a global organization. Back then, I found myself leaning in whenever she talked about big changes happening at her office. 

What struck me, even as a kid, was a clear pattern: when changes were significant, her leadership team went above and beyond to make the office environment collaborative and supportive. They held town halls, brought in specialized trainers, and one memorable summer they even had an ice cream truck visit the office every Friday.  

I realize now that her leadership team understood something fundamental, which is that successful change management isn‚Äôt just about rolling out new tools, it‚Äôs about considering the human impact. My mom happily worked for that organization for years and even recruited me to intern there. That‚Äôs the power of thoughtful change management. 

So how can you model what my mom experienced when implementing AI in SAP Ariba or SAP Fieldglass? Let's look at the playbook. 

Clear Communications: Everyone Deserves to Know the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù 

The first lesson from my mom's experience was transparency. Her leadership team didn't just announce changes, they explained the "why" behind their decisions and created multiple ways for employees to understand and engage.  

When you're implementing AI in procurement, develop a robust communication strategy that addresses where you're deploying it and the rationale behind those choices. Maybe you‚Äôre: 

  • Rolling out the AI-assisted SAP Ariba Category Management solution because it saves your team multiple hours per week by automating category analysis, enabling them to become strategic advisors with better data and faster identification of new business opportunities. 
  • Piloting intelligent resume analysis‚ÄØin SAP Fieldglass because it highlights top talent for hiring managers, giving them more time to focus on their core responsibilities while gaining a competitive advantage in talent acquisition. 

Be upfront about your reasoning. Use multiple communication channels that feel natural to your organization. Town halls work well for big-picture strategy and allowing open questions. "Ask Me Anything" sessions give employees a safe space to voice concerns. But don't stop there - weave updates into established channels like company newsletters, team meetings, and other standardized communications your teams already utilize and trust. 

Most importantly, identify and leverage internal champions early in your communication strategy. These trusted team members can help translate technical concepts into practical benefits and address concerns from their peers‚Äô perspective. When your teams have questions, take the time to answer them thoughtfully. This isn't just courtesy; it's essential for adoption. 

Special Training Programs: Don't Skip This Step 

Here‚Äôs where many organizations stumble. They want to skip comprehensive training and assume people will figure out AI-driven tools on their own. Don‚Äôt make this mistake. 

First, Get Your Data Foundation Right 

Before you can train effectively, you need clean data. AI works best when the underlying data is structured, reliable, and consistently maintained, but many procurement organizations struggle with data that‚Äôs scattered across systems. Supplier names often vary between purchase orders and contracts and spend categories don‚Äôt align across business units. This fragmentation creates obstacles to adoption. 

That‚Äôs why you need to start by explaining how AI works within your solutions. When a user sees an AI-generated recommendation in SAP Ariba or an AI-generated statement of work (SOW) description in SAP Fieldglass, they should understand which data inputs created that content and why it matters.  

Then, Focus on User Training  

  • With Joule, show users how conversational AI accesses your organization‚Äôs information and best practices, demonstrating why instant access to critical data improves their decision-making capabilities 
  • With SAP Ariba, help users understand how market and historical data analysis creates real-time category strategy, supplier insights, and RFP recommendations, enabling them to make confident decisions and respond faster to changing conditions  
  • With SAP Fieldglass, explain how basic project inputs generate comprehensive descriptions for both job descriptions and SOWs, so hiring managers can trust AI-enhanced deliverables while focusing on strategic workforce planning 

Finally, Nurture and Support your Champions 

Your champions will help drive your success and should also be involved in validating AI recommendations during pilot phases. When they can vouch for the accuracy and usefulness of AI-generated insights, your solutions will be more impactful and their endorsement will carry a lot of weight, just like my mom‚Äôs feedback did at her organization. Keep your champions engaged by recognizing their contributions publicly, providing them with exclusive previews of new features, and regularly asking them for their input on product improvements. Personalized attention helps maintain their enthusiasm and advocacy.  

Your team won't automatically love new features just because they're AI-driven. You need to train them properly, communicate quick wins clearly, and continuously drive adoption.   

Ice Cream for Everyone: The Human Element Matters 

That summer, my mom made it her mission to try every flavor from that ice cream truck. She‚Äôd come home excited to tell us about both the ice cream and the wins, big and small, that her team was racking up with their new processes. And the best part? The changes let her spend more time digging into the more interesting, complex invoices instead of processing the easy ones that were never flagged.   

The small gestures mattered as much as the robust communication plans and training programs, creating an environment where change felt celebratory rather than threatening. 

Don't underestimate the human element that comes with any significant change. While AI-enabled solutions like SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass ensure there's always a human in the loop, people still feel natural apprehension about adopting tools that are designed to drive efficiency. They wonder if their expertise will still be valued, if their jobs will change, or if they'll be able to master new ways of working.  

Address this directly by highlighting how AI creates opportunities for greater visibility and strategic impact. For example:   

  • Joule eliminates information bottlenecks‚ÄØby making information conversationally accessible. It puts details like purchasing insights and hiring best practices at users‚Äô fingertips. 
  • Sourcing and Bid Analysis Agents‚ÄØin SAP Ariba solutions reduce decision-making stress and increase agility by analyzing market and historical data to create and adapt RFPs in real time. This gives users confidence in purchasing decisions and faster responses to supply chain disruptions while freeing them to focus on negotiations and relationship building. 
  • The SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution elevates user roles by automating invoice processing where key thresholds are met. This reduces manual data entry so teams can focus on high-value exception management and build stronger vendor relationships. 
  • AI-assisted SOW creation tools in SAP Fieldglass applications streamline project planning by generating comprehensive descriptions from basic project inputs, enabling hiring managers to create detailed SOWs faster. The tools also drive consistency across templates and projects, which helps users shift from administrative workforce management to strategic talent optimization. 

The key is showing employees that AI elevates their expertise rather than replacing it, much like how my mom's new systems and processes made her work more strategic and less manual.  

Change Management Best Practices Actually Work 

Successful AI adoption follows the same change management approach that worked for my mom's organization years ago: clear communication, comprehensive training, genuine support, and celebration of progress. It‚Äôs a timeless template for transformation. 

  • Communicate clearly and frequently about what's changing and why. 
  • Invest in comprehensive training that's tailored for all skill levels. 
  • Create‚ÄØopportunities for feedback and iteration. 
  • Acknowledge that change is challenging and provide support.   

Most importantly, keep the human experience at the center of your implementation strategy. Technology should make people's work more interesting and valuable, not more complicated or uncertain.   

When procurement professionals can spend less time on data compilation and more time on strategic initiatives, have better insights to inform negotiations, and respond more quickly to business needs ‚Äî that's when AI becomes fun and transformational.  

By getting this right, you ensure that your teams won't just adopt AI, they'll become advocates for it. They‚Äôll share success stories and help scale the transformation across your organization, and they'll talk about how much fun they‚Äôre having at the dinner table, just like my mom did.  

Ready to optimize your company's approach to AI? Check out the AI-based solutions that are already embedded in your SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass applications on our SAP Business AI for procurement webpage.

entry.title: Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing
entry.content:
Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing

Follow the below blog from Nageshcaparthy and want to highlight couple of things which this blog didn‚Äôt cover and couple of changes were needed in SAP help document which is informed to SAP product team during my interaction.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-integration-with-sap-ariba-setup-guide/ba-p/14240003

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/integration-with-sap-ariba

We should consider 2 scenarios

  1. Customers who have already integrated SAP Ariba with SSO.
  2. Those who are 1st time implementing SAP Ariba with SSO and integrating with SAP Joule

Scenario 1:

Since we belong in this category I want to share changes observed during this whole process and my experience through this article.

Activation of Joule and formations were already in place and SAP Successfactor integration completed successfully.

Comparing the steps from the blog and at the same time highlighting the changes

  1. Steps involved during this integration
  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services (ICM Process) ‚Äì completed
  2. OAuth Credentials for CDM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal) ‚Äì We needed not only these keys but SCIM API for User and Group Master Data.
  3. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from SAP Ariba Applications to IAS
    1. Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System
    2. Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System
  4. Integrating Joule
  • Have an existing Joule setup, and a formation has been created
  1. Post-integration checks
  • Validate Application List
  • Validate the Attributes
  • Trusted Domains
  • Conditional Authentication
  1. Destination Setup
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations
    1. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations ‚Äì DT
    2. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations ‚Äì RT
  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider 
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions
  • Channel Updates
  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Configure the Source System
  • Configure Target Systems
    • SAP Ariba Sourcing ‚Äì Target
    • Run Sync Job

During my session along with SAP Development team it was clarified that the users sync from IAS to Ariba were not required as it was not required since SAP Ariba was already integrated with IAS for SSO and users in both were already in Sync.

please read the disclaimer from referred blog.

  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services

since this configuration is already in place and ensured that joule activation was done using the same IAS tenant which was used earlier for integration with SAP Successfactor and the same should be used for other LOB‚Äôs. If other LOBs are configured with different IAS tenants then you may have to migrate them to this IAS tenant it will be really challenging. As highlighted in my earlier blog this requires proper planning for unification of all the SAP LOBs into a single IAS tenant.

We had details discussion with SAP Team about the critical aspect of GUID (SCIM ID) ‚Äì All along I had an impression that GUID were required for user authentication and conversations and it requires to send this information from IAS to Ariba which was not required as Ariba doesn‚Äôt depend on it entirely rather it uses other attributes of the user like email ID and Login name even though Ariba uses S4HANA in the backend it is completely controlled from Application side.

 The question will arise what about S4HANA either cloud or on-premise systems to be integrated with Joule how the GUID will be taken care of. It entirely depends on the way the users from IAS to these LOBs are sync. Once we achieved it part of Task center implementation is that the GUID of uses from IAS were updated into S4HANA on premise (existing setup) using BADI. You can refer to any blog or online information you will find the details.

As per the blog we changed the url from ondemand.com to cloud.sap with the help of Ariba team since as customer you don‚Äôt have an option to change it.

Since already we had the existing setup of Ariba integration with IAS there are no source and target systems created in IDP.

Thankfully the blog has provided the json files for source system and target system which we used and manually created them for replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS.

In the blog and in help document it is mentioned that once the above step is completed we should have the necessary bundled applications, Source, target systems in IAS which didn‚Äôt happen in our case since we already had the necessary application defined manually for integration of Ariba with IAS. I recommend this to be included in any of the blogs or in the help document so that customer is aware of it.

Sourcing system

Target system

  1. OAuth Credentials for SCIM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal)

Follow the steps mentioned in the blog and the difference is we faced issue with replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS and after session with Ariba team advised us to create SCIM API in place CDM API created using workzone CDM Content and these details are meant to use in source system of users and groups replication from IAS to Workzone. The details of SCIM API requested through SAP Ariba Development Portal. It is possible to get both API‚Äôs by creating the incident as we didn‚Äôt find the workzone CDM API in the portal and it is created and sent to us by Ariba team except creation of secret which can be done by the administrator of portal.

3.1 Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System

Created the source system using the json files provided in the blog and used the SCIM API created earlier in the Development portal.

3.2 Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System

The user and password are taken from a system user created in the administrator console with client ID and secret by providing only the necessary auth. to manage users and groups.

Followed other recommendations provided in the blog to remove some property parameters

Replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS is successful. check the below details from provisioning logs.

Note: Moment of caution again don‚Äôt sync user replication from IAS to Ariba which is not required it may differ in terms of specific cases and would advise to take the help of Ariba team.

  1. Integrating Joule

As we already had the existing setup of joule with formations ready we added the Ariba realm and ended with the issue below. Not providing complete details as they are already covered in the blog.

Synchronization was failing as it was unable to identify already created application in IAS. After weeks long investigation by Joule and Ariba product development team they created one more application other than already existing one added the missing client ID inside the attributes of the application, and we were able to add the Ariba tenant successfully into the formation.

Production development still they are trying to figure out the issue and hopefully in subsequent release the process will identify the existing application in IAS which will create the necessary bundle application under the main application.

After successfully adding the Ariba tenant still joule icon was not appearing in the Ariba tenant and further it was resolved by Ariba team after activating feature toggles in Ariba tenant.

  1. Post-integration checks

Follow the validation of attributes, application, Changes in the trusted domain, Conditional authentication at IAS as mentioned in the blog.

  1. Destination Setup

Follow and create destination of Design time and runtime as mentioned in the blog and use the files provided in github.

https://github.com/SAP-samples/btp-onboarding/tree/main/docs/Joule-with-SAP-Ariba/JSON-Files

  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions

Following the steps mentioned in the blog and initial update will fail since still users and groups were not replicated from IAS to Ariba.

  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone

We had issue with creation of source system in IDP for replication of users and groups ( As per the blog it should create automatically once the IAS tenant is added in to ICM which didn‚Äôt create in our case) json files were also missing in the blog. Requested the product development to add them into the same github repository.

Followed the help document to create the source and target systems in IDP.

Execution of sync job should be successful once you ensured that property parameters in both source and target systems are properly maintained.

Now if a refresh is done for SAP Ariba strategic sourcing in Workzone it should be updated successfully.

verify whether the groups are assigned to the users..

I had an interesting discussion with SAP Product team why not Ariba also follows the same way users and groups are replicated from SF to WZ during integration of SAP Successfactor with Joule (where they are directly moved from SF to WZ by passing the IAS where IAS is used only for authentication). In Ariba the users and groups are replicated from Ariba-IAS-WZ. The explanation is that both products are different in the way they interact with BTP. SF is part of BTP whereas Ariba is completely different SAAS product.

 

  1. Joule Test Scenarios

Follow the use cases from the below link. Test each case end to end understand all the scenarios application like Informational, Transactional, Navigational.

Note that beyond the scenarios what are explained and configured to work in Joule don‚Äôt execute in you natural language as you won‚Äôt find a proper response.

Each interaction user make with joule and response received will be treated as one token and as I mentioned in my earlier blog ‚ÄúAriba integration with SAP successfactor ‚Äúyou are entitled for fixed number messages free and after that you will be charged so understanding the scenarios and educating the business users adhering to it is critical as of now. Not sure if SAP increases the number of messages free.

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/capabilities-guide/joule-in-sap-ariba-solutions

 

Conclusion: The Next Generation of Procurement

The integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing is a significant step toward an AI-driven, friction-less procurement process. This implementation journey, especially for customers with existing SSO configurations, underscores that while official documentation is really useful but it requires changes for both scenarios mentioned.

Key Takeaways and Future Focus

This experience highlights several vital points for organizations embarking on this integration:

  • IAS Unification: The seamless integration of Joule across multiple Line of Business (LOB) applications, like SuccessFactors and Ariba, hinges on the unification of all LOBs to a single SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) tenant. This prevents complex migration challenges and ensures a cohesive user experience.

  • User Sync: For customers already integrated via SSO, the blog's requirement for a separate IAS-to-Ariba user sync can be potentially eliminated or simplified, as Ariba primarily relies on existing attributes like email and login name for authentication, not the GUID/SCIM ID for conversation context, which is the main dependency for other applications like S4HANA, SuccessFactors and SAP concur.

  • Beyond the Standard API: The need to request the SCIM API in addition to the standard OAuth Credentials (CDM API) for user and group replication from Ariba to IAS is a practical detail that requires a proactive approach with the SAP Ariba development team.

  • The Maturing Platform: The initial issues faced with the Joule application identification in IAS and the subsequent need for Ariba team intervention to activate feature toggles demonstrate that the Joule integration architecture, while robust, is still actively maturing. Future releases are expected to streamline the automatic identification and bundling of applications within IAS.

In summary, this integration has successfully delivered the conversational and transactional capabilities of the Joule AI Copilot into the SAP Ariba Sourcing landscape. As SAP continues to invest in generative AI, understanding these practical implementation insights will be crucial for other enterprises to achieve a truly unified, intelligent, and highly efficient procurement experience while maximizing the value of their existing SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: From Intelligent Applications to Trusted Data: Accelerating Insight to Action for Business Analysts
entry.content:
Business analysts today are expected to turn complex datasets into insight faster than ever; analyzing trends, spotting opportunities, and ultimately providing line-of-business leaders with the information necessary to make informed decisions. To meet these demands, they need tools that simplify analysis, ensure data quality, and accelerate their path from question to actionable insight. 

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP announced a suite of advancements designed to do just that‚Äîcontinuing to drive momentum across its data and AI portfolio. New intelligent applications, expanded access to curated data products in SAP Business Data Cloud, and deeper AI-driven assistance powered by Joule empower analysts to work smarter, make faster decisions, and deliver insights with confidence, all while maintaining governance and accuracy at every step.

Intelligent Applications: Purpose-Built Insights for Every Line of Business 

Intelligent applications in SAP Business Data Cloud continue to evolve, giving analysts prebuilt, AI-driven insights across domains like finance, HR, supply chain, and more. By embedding more intelligence directly into everyday workflows, these applications let analysts start with much of the foundational work already modeled, monitored, and enriched with AI‚Äîso they can focus on understanding trends, identifying gaps, and answering the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind the data, rather than the mechanics of assembling it.  

The Value of Intelligent Applications at a Glance: 

  • Consistent, trusted data sources resulting in reliable, repeatable insights 
  • Less manual prep work and more time spent analyzing and interpreting 
  • Shorter analysis cycles through immediate access to prebuilt dashboards 
  • Higher trust and alignment through unified metrics and premodeled insights 
  • Clearer explanations behind anomalies, trends, and performance drivers
  • AI-enhanced recommendations tailored to each line of business 

Intelligent Applications by Line of Business

Key Updates and Expanded Use Cases 

Following up on the intelligent application announcement made at SAP Sapphire in 2025, SAP has expanded both previews and general availability. Spend Intelligence, Supply Chain Intelligence, and Revenue Intelligence are now in restricted public preview, while Finance Intelligence, People Intelligence, and Cloud ERP Intelligence private packages are generally available. Together, these additions broaden the library of ready-to-use insights business analysts can tap into with minimal setup.

  • People Intelligence: New HR-focused use cases now deliver deeper insight into recruiting, learning effectiveness, and employee performance. Analysts gain more accurate attrition predictions and intuitive dashboards that make it easy to compare trends and risks across business units.  
  • Revenue Intelligence: Expanded capabilities provide revenue and sales leaders with a real-time, holistic view of pipeline performance. These updates combine continuously learning ML forecasts, automated variance detection, and unified insights across sales, finance, and operations to support more predictable planning and decision-making. 
  • Consumer Products Intelligence: A new intelligent application for consumer goods manufacturers helps optimize trade promotion planning and manage spending with greater precision. Features include real-time price elasticity analysis, promotion effectiveness insights, margin optimization tools, and streamlined workflows for executing financial operations. 

Trusted Data Products Fueling Reliable, Reusable Insights 

Data products remain one of the most impactful pillars of SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äîespecially for analysts who need quick access to context-rich and ready-to-use business data. Instead of repeatedly rebuilding the same datasets for each analysis or project, analysts can tap into governed, out-of-the-box data products that are automatically kept up to date. This not only eliminates duplication but also ensures that everyone across functional teams are working from the same source of truth. By standardizing reusable models, metrics, and pipelines, analysts gain a foundation that speeds up reporting cycles and reduces back-and-forth with technical teams. 

In summary, here's what data products bring to the table for business analysts: 

  • Reusable datasets reduce manual preparation and accelerate reporting cycles 
  • Shared metrics and models ensure consistent definitions across teams 
  • Faster insight generation with less time spent requesting or rebuilding data 
  • Increased trust in data quality, making findings easier to validate and share 

Momentum Continues: More Data Products Across SAP Applications 

SAP is expanding its catalog of ready-to-use data products across critical application areas, including SAP Cloud ERP, SAP SuccessFactors, sustainability, and customer experience. These additions will be available in SAP Business Data Cloud in H1 2026, giving business analysts access to richer, more discoverable datasets to support planning, reporting, and advanced analysis.

Overview: Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud

AI Assistants and Augmented Workflows: Work Smarter, Act Faster 

SAP‚Äôs latest advancements in AI assistants and automation deliver clear benefits to business analysts. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) already offers strong AI capabilities, including natural language querying and machine learning-powered insights, that provide analysts with a robust foundation for faster data exploration and discovery. 

SAP is extending SAC with even more powerful, automated, and generative workflows designed to accelerate both analysis and planning: 

  • Story Generation Agent ‚Äì Automatically transforms raw data, business context, and user prompts into complete, insight-rich SAC stories or intelligent applications. It assembles visualizations, narrative structure, and recommendations using reusable components and user preferences. 
  • AI-assisted workflows for planning and analytics ‚Äì Includes comment summarization, comment translation, and natural language generation of advanced formulas. Analysts can describe complex planning logic conversationally and have SAC generate or refine the script behind it.
  • Joule embedded natively in SAC ‚Äì Provides in-context conversational support to help analysts refine queries, adjust dashboards, troubleshoot logic, or accelerate iterative analysis directly within the product. 

Joule Capabilities in SAP Analytics Cloud (2026)

Why This All Matters for Business Analysts 

Across intelligent applications, curated data products, and AI-assisted workflows, the message is clear: SAP is removing the friction that slows analysts down and elevating their work to more strategic, impactful roles. Built natively into SAP Business Data Cloud, these capabilities ensure analysts can work within a single, unified environment where data, analysis, and decision support are seamlessly connected. Analysts can now rely on workflows that are more automated, consistent, and cross-functionally integrated. The outcome: faster answers to critical business questions, clearer recommendations for business leaders, and more time spent on the high-value analytical work that drives real business impact. 

To learn more about SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP‚Äôs latest announcements: 

  • Visit SAP Business Data Cloud on sap.com 
  • Read the H2 2025 SAP Innovation Guide for key highlights 
  • Watch the replays from SAP TechEd 2025 virtual sessions: 
    • SAP Business Data Cloud solution road map (DA806v)
    • Planning and analytics: Innovations powering SAP Business Data Cloud (DA207v) 
    • Transforming how people work with Joule technology (ST123v) 
  • Get hands-on with the SAP BDC Getting Started workshop series (on-demand)

In addition, you can explore other innovations from SAP BDC by persona: for Data Stewards/Owners and Data Scientists.

entry.title: Agent Mining in SAP Signavio: Understand agent behavior
entry.content:
AI agents are transforming enterprise operations‚Äîautonomously interpreting data, making decisions, and executing tasks; but as you scale your use of AI, a new challenge emerges: how do you truly understand what your agents are doing, why they act the way they do, and what their return on investment really is?

That‚Äôs the value of the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio solutions ‚Äîto bring visibility, accountability, and continuous optimization to the growing ecosystem of AI-driven process transformation.

The Problem: Invisible Autonomy in Enterprise AI

As AI agents become more autonomous, their behavior may become more ambiguous. Their decisions happen in milliseconds, driven by complex reasoning or LLM-based inference that isn‚Äôt always visible to end users.

This creates critical business questions:

  •  What specific actions are my agents taking within my processes and how they are impacting them?
  • Are they acting in compliance to my rules and policies?
  • How much does it cost to run them?
  • Are they actually delivering measurable business value?

Without transparency, organizations risk unpredictable outcomes‚Äîagents that operate efficiently on paper but unpredictably in practice, potentially introducing errors, inefficiencies, or unnecessary costs.

Discover agent mining in SAP Signavio

Agent mining enables organizations to understand and optimize the behavior of AI agents operating across their business processes. It provides the ability to:

  • Trace agent behavior: See how agents make decisions, navigate process steps, and adapt to different contexts.
  • Analyze impact: Measure the agents‚Äô influence on key metrics like process time, accuracy, and compliance.
  • Monitor cost: Track computational or LLM-related expenses to ensure cost-efficient performance.
  • Benchmark performance: Compare agent iterations to identify areas for refinement.

Agent Mining is available natively for SAP Joule Agents, but it can also extend to third-party or custom-built agents, offering a unique and unified lens across your AI landscape.

The Broader Vision: AI Agent Excellence

Agent mining is one of four pillars of our comprehensive approach to AI agent excellence, ensuring that intelligent agents operate efficiently with the necessary process context while being safely adopted in full compliance and governance.

  1. Agent discovery ‚Äì Identify the right processes and opportunities where AI agents can drive the greatest impact.
  2. Agent context ‚Äì Provide agents with the right process knowledge and compliance parameters to act responsibly and efficiently.
  3. Agent mining ‚Äì Observe and analyze how agents actually behave in operation‚Äîwhat decisions they take, how they perform, and how much they cost.
  4. Agent value impact ‚Äì Quantify the business value that agents deliver, such as efficiency gains, cost savings, or improved customer experience.

Together, these pillars ensure that organizations not only build AI agents for processes but continuously learn from and improve them to ensure compliance, governance and safe adoption into enterprise organizations.

A Real-World Example: The Accounts Receivable Agent

Consider the SAP‚Äôs Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent, which automates parts of the order-to-cash cycle. This agent matches payments to open invoices, interprets remittance advice, sends reminders for overdue accounts, and escalates exceptions for human review. The agent can help produce important benefits, for example, it helps reduce Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) by prioritizing the closure of open items and surfacing high-value follow-up actions. It analyzes behavioral patterns to anticipate risk, recommend next best actions, and support users with meaningful, context-aware insights.

By leveraging the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio, the AR team can analyze the agent behaviour and understand why or how those results are achieved, and more specifically:

  • Observe decision patterns: Understand when the agent decides to match invoices automatically versus escalating them.
  • Identify cost drivers: Detect cases where complex remittance language triggers costly LLM inference cycles.
  • Evaluate process impact: Quantify how agent-driven automation reduces days sales outstanding (DSO) or exception-handling time.
  • Optimize agent logic: Spot recurring scenarios that lead to human overrides and refine the agent‚Äôs contextual knowledge accordingly.

For example, if the mining data shows that certain customers‚Äô remittance notes consistently confuse the agent, the team can retrain the model or adjust confidence thresholds‚Äîcutting costs and improving accuracy.

The Next Chapter: From a Single Agent to a Multi-Agent System

Building on the Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent example, we now take a step further‚Äîfrom understanding one agent‚Äôs behavior to analyzing an entire ecosystem of agents working together. In many real-world scenarios, business outcomes aren‚Äôt driven by a single autonomous agent but by a network of collaborating agents that coordinate to solve broader, cross-functional challenges.

Let‚Äôs now imagine a hypothetical scenario where the Accounts Receivable Agent operates alongside other agents such as one for order management, one for billing, and one supporting customer communication . Together in this example, they form a multi-agent system that manages the complete order-to-cash lifecycle‚Äîautomatically resolving discrepancies, predicting late payments, and even initiating proactive customer outreach.

By applying multi-agent mining within SAP Signavio, process experts such as process owners, managers and analysts can uncover not just what individual agents do, but how they interact and collectively drive business performance. This enables them to:

  • Discover collaboration dynamics: Analyze how agents exchange information or trigger actions across processes to achieve shared goals.
  • Detect coordination gaps: Identify where hand-offs between agents cause delays, redundancies, or missed insights.
  • Measure systemic impact: Evaluate how agent collaboration influences high-level KPIs such as cash flow, customer satisfaction, or process cycle time.
  • Refine orchestration rules: Optimize the logic that governs when and how agents should intervene or communicate for maximum efficiency.

For example, if mining data reveals that the agent supporting billing often waits for the  agent for accounts receivable to complete validation before sending invoices‚Äîcreating unnecessary latency‚Äîthe orchestration can be adjusted to allow parallel execution with confidence thresholds. This evolution‚Äîfrom analyzing a single agent to optimizing a network of agents‚Äîdemonstrates how agent mining at scale can transform isolated automation into an intelligent, collaborative digital workforce.

In the following demonstration, we show how multi-agent mining in SAP Signavio reveals collaboration patterns between a series of fictious agents.. By analyzing their interactions, we uncover coordination gaps, optimize orchestration, and see how their combined behavior drives end-to-end business performance.

 

Why Agent Mining Matters

Agent mining is more than a monitoring capability‚Äî It provides a new level of visibility and measurable insights empowering organizations to:

  • Increase transparency into agent behavior and decision logic.
  • Control operational costs by understanding and optimizing LLM usage.
  • Ensure compliance through auditable decision trails.
  • Continuously improve performance by learning from live agent execution.
  • Measure true business value of AI automation, not just efficiency metrics.

From Discovery to Value

Agent mining is core to maximize the impact of AI agent deployments and attain AI agent excellence. From discovering where to deploy agents, to contextualizing their operations, to measuring their impact, mining provides the visibility needed for responsible, high-performance AI agent adoption.

The result: AI agents that don‚Äôt just work‚Äîthey work transparently, efficiently, and strategically.

With SAP Signavio capabilities for agent mining, organizations can finally see, understand, and optimize the invisible intelligence powering their digital processes.

If you have any questions on agent mining, please feel free to reach out to me by commenting down below. Also check out our AI Agent excellence page to gain more insights.

entry.title: Where Is My Stuff? ‚Äî Joule‚Äôs First Industry Release Brings AI-Driven Insight to Oil and Gas Upstream
entry.content:
The oil and gas domain has historically been one of the most stable but also conservative areas of enterprise architecture. Over multiple decades, SAP customers have evolved from custom ABAP solutions to standardized S/4HANA objects, Fiori applications, and integrated complex logistics planning and processes. While this has driven consistency and transactional efficiency, the core decision-making mechanisms in field logistics remained predominantly human-driven with, manual validation, and the experience of field and personnel.

SAP Field Logistics is a solution built on SAP S/4HANA. It is available on both S/4HANA private cloud and public cloud.  This solution enables customers leverage best in class industry practices to manage the logistics movement of their own- and third-party items between their supply and demand plants. 

We are happy to announce that in May 2025, we at SAP introduced a landmark innovation:

the very first Joule-enabled capability across all industries, delivered specifically within SAP Upstream Field Logistics.

This early release is subtle in scope but monumental in strategic significance. It marks the beginning of Field Logistics evolution from traditional business processes to a future where core FL operations become deeply AI-driven through Joule.

A Strategic First Step: Joule‚Äôs Inventory Insights for FL

The initial capability released in May focuses on a read-only non-stock inventory scenario, allowing users to retrieve consolidated product and equipment visibility through natural language and gives the latest milestone of its lifecycle to help to know where the equipment is located. Even though this first use case is intentionally controlled, it is designed as the foundation for a multi-release future where Joule will perform full field logistics (FL) transactions end-to-end.

SAP‚Äôs intention is clear:

Start small, prove value, ensure reliability, and then scale AI-driven operations across the entire upstream lifecycle.

This first release demonstrates Joule‚Äôs ability to:

  • Understand Field Logistics terminology in 50 different languages
  • Interpret users queries through Natural Language Processing and provide contextual answers instantly
  • Display list of products along with relevant information‚Äôs like plant, Purchase order, different quantities etc
  • Navigate to Manage logistics application from Joule to get a wholistic view

While simple on the surface, the underlying architecture sets the stage for powerful, future-ready logistics automation.

What This Means for Customers

 Faster, simpler access to operational intelligence

Users can ask Joule questions in natural language ‚Äî no need to navigate complex screens or interpret multiple reports.

Immediate visibility where it matters most

Inventory and material readiness have direct impact on non-productive time.

A future-proof foundation for autonomous logistics

This first release is intentionally scoped ‚Äî but designed for expansion into item receival, returns process, and more.

A clear step toward an ‚ÄúAI co-pilot‚Äù for upstream operations

Joule is not just a search tool. It is the beginning of a more intelligent, proactive, and predictive logistics environment.

Technical Highlights Behind the Scenes

While the customer experience focuses on simplicity, the technical implementation is sophisticated:

Flow Diagram

1. Semantic Understanding of FL and S/4HANA Operational Objects

Joule interprets upstream-specific structures such as:

  • Field Logistics items
  • PO, GR, Open and Return quantity
  • Latest Milestone
  • Non-stock Inventory availability data

This domain-awareness is what enables Joule to deliver precise, contextual answers.

2. Natural Language ‚Üí CDS Query Generation

Joule automatically translates plain language into data retrieval operations using:

  • CDS consumption views
  • FL OData APIs

This eliminates the need for custom queries or separate analytical tool.

Functionality:

Do follow the below link to understand about Joule and how to access the same in a Private Cloud system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-a-comprehensive-setup-guide/ba-p/13786453

Once you login to your Fiori system as a Supply Chain Analyst persona and click on the Joule icon at the top, all the capabilities that are part of your user role will be available. Users also can click on helpful conversation starters instead of asking a question.

Certain mandatory parameters are needed to process the user utterance, for our capability the item number/ description must be provided. Additionally, optional parameters like plant could also be provided to narrow down the search results.

Joule displays a list of items that are relevant for your search along with some important fields such as PO and item, Latest Milestone.

You can click on each entry which would take you to a detail view wherein additional fields such as Order and various quantities can be viewed.

Also, there is a button at the bottom which can be used to Navigate to Manage Logistics application that filters the data already entered by the user.

 

Customer-Focused Future Roadmap

SAP has already signalled a multi-release roadmap to expand Joule‚Äôs Oil and Gas capabilities beyond visibility into actionable intelligence and automated logistics execution.

The Future Vision

This progression reflects SAP‚Äôs commitment to controlled, safe, value-driven rollout of Joule capabilities to field logistics operations.

Conclusion: A Small Release with a Massive Strategic Horizon

The May 2025 Joule capability for FL may be limited to inventory visibility, but it represents:

  • The first-ever Joule release across industries
  • The foundation of AI-enriched S/4HANA FL operations
  • The beginning of SAP‚Äôs broader AI transformation across line-of-business functions

Customers leveraging this early capability are not just gaining a new feature‚Äîthey are positioning themselves at the frontline of an industry-wide shift, where SAP systems evolve from transactional engines to intelligent co-pilots for complex field logistics operations.

entry.title: msg group Accelerates Innovation with SAP Joule for Developers
entry.content:

About msg group 

With 25 years of experience in SAP products as well as custom development, msg group specializes in delivering innovative SAP solutions that help businesses run better. As a trusted SAP gold partner, they focus on state-of-the-art solution development leveraging modern ABAP Cloud techniques. 

 

The Challenge

ABAP AI enabled their developers to work smarter, not harder, freeing up time to focus on delivering business-critical innovations. 

 

The Results 

By adopting ABAP AI, msg group achieved measurable improvements: 

  • 20% increase in speed during the analysis of legacy ABAP code. 
  • Significant time savings for the initial generation of unit tests for ABAP classes and core data services. 
  • Increased developer productivity, allowing teams to focus on critical tasks and support other projects. 

Overall, this meant faster delivery of solutions, reduced costs, and higher satisfaction among all stakeholders. 

Learn more about msg‚Äôs use case here. 

 

Partner Perspective 

‚ÄúSAP Joule for Developers is an essential part of the modern ABAP Cloud developer‚Äôs toolbox. It accelerates development with practical, high-impact use cases while empowering developers to decide how and where to apply it. This approach enables us to deliver innovation faster than ever ‚Äî without compromising the quality our customers trust.‚Äù 
‚Äî Sebastian Freilinger-Huber, Principal IT Consultant, msg group 

 

Looking Ahead 

Building on these early successes, msg group plans to expand ABAP AI adoption across all business areas and projects developed on SAP BTP ABAP Environment and S/4HANA Cloud (Public and Private Edition). With SAP‚Äôs continued investment in AI, msg group is well-positioned to drive ongoing innovation and customer value. 

SAP Joule for Developers now unlocks even more potential with the new Custom Code Migration capabilities. These features streamline the transformation of classic ABAP code for SAP S/4HANA, making it easier to analyze, adapt, and modernize custom code with built-in explanations and guidance. For partners like msg group, it significantly reduces the effort required to transition customers to S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äî while maintaining quality and accelerating time to value. 

 

Learn More 

Want to dive deeper into capabilities and use cases?  

Learn more about SAP BTP ABAP environment and  SAP Joule for Developers to explore how AI capabilities in SAP Build, including ABAP Environment, can transform your development workflows.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Joule - Performance&Goals Agent Activation
entry.content:
Hi AI and Joule enthusiasts,

I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve been following the release updates and saw the H2 highlights on agentic AI for SuccessFactors.

Joule in SuccessFactors now supports its first agent for Performance and Goals - designed to help managers prepare for employee performance reviews.

For more details on the agent, please see: Performance and Goals Agent

 

If you are looking for the implementation steps you are very welcome to read the rest of the blog because I like to share the steps to get the agent activated and how you can test / trigger the agent.

 

Pre-Requisites for Agent Activation:

- Licenses: AI Units

- Joule for SuccessFactors is activated

 

Recommendation for PM/GM Agent Usage:

To maximize the effectiveness of the Performance and Goals Agent, we strongly recommend enabling one or more of the following modules: Performance Management, Goal Management, and Continuous Performance Management. This allows the agent to access relevant data from direct reports and provide more valuable analyses and actionable insights.

 

Activation Steps:

1. Activate the Agent in SuccessFactors:

  • Login to your SuccessFactors System
  • go to Admin Center  -> AI Services Administration ->  enable the Performance & Goals Agent

The Agent is currently marked as Base AI because we run a promotion phase (planned until Mai 2026). Please check the license model starting in April/Mail.

2. Assign Permissions to Manager: 

  • Login to your SuccessFactors System
  • assign permissions to your relevant permission roles: User Permissions ->  AI Access -> Performance & Goals Agent

The Agent is designed for Managers incl. access to employee details. Employees would not have access to the agents for there self.

3. Refresh CDM contents

  • login to your BTP Global Account
  • select the subaccount where Joule is implemented
  • login to the WorkZone Application assigned to the global account

 

  • Run a content channel refresh

  • after the successful refresh check the content manager -> a new Role should be added

Required activation Steps are done. Now you can wait that your regular jobs (SF - Refresh synchtetic Group Data and IPS - User/Group Synch to WorkZone) runs. If you want to test immediately you can also trigger this 2 jobs.

4. Trigger refresh synthetic group data job in SuccessFactors

  • login to your SuccessFactors System
  • go to Admin Center - > Scheduled Job Manager
  • Search for the refresh synthetic group data job and start the job 
    • If you have more then one job or not the explizite deepLinkActivatonPermission Job make sure you select the job that includes the deepLinkActivatonPermission as object

  • How to check: click on the Job to get the job details. As JobParameter "All" or "Common Data Model Content Deep-Link Access User Group" should be selected

 

 

5. Run IPS Job

After successful update of the Content Channel and a successful run of the SF job you can trigger your IPS Job.

  • login to your Cloud Identity Service System
  • Select Identity Provisioning -> Source System
  • Select the source system that feeds your Joule WorkZone System
  • Go to Jobs and run the Read or Re-Synch Job

6. Check the Group assignment

If all the jobs was successful users with Agent permissions should receive a new group in WorkZone. If you want to check this do the following:

  • login to your BTP Global Account
  • select the subaccount where Joule is implemented
  • login to the WorkZone Application assigned to the global account
  • select Settings -> Identity Provisioning
  • search for the global user id of a relevant manager

 

  • check if the Role is assigned  (the ID 8074 was created in my demo system, please search for your relevant id from step 3)

 

7. Test the agent

  • login to SuccessFactors as a manager
  • open Joule
  • trigger the Agent (the agent collects a lot of data and prepares details for you - be patient it will take a while)

 

Some sample prompts for working with the agent:

  • trigger the agent: Please help me to prepare my performance review meeting with <Employees Name>
  • some ideas you can ask the agent:
    • can you show me some more details on the received feedbacks?  [if continuous feedback is activated and used]
    • can you create a summary of the current existing performance forms?
    • can you summarize the goals and the status of achievement?

 

Have fun with testing.

 

Let us know in the comments what your favorite prompts during the usage are.

entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

‚úîÔ∏è On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

‚ùì On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is a brand new classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research ‚ÄúAgents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI‚Äù says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI‚Äôs massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: ‚ÄúIn one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated‚Äù said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added ‚ÄúThere are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine‚Ä¶ perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? üôÉ

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: REGISTER NOW: SAP Joule Agents in SAP Signavio Beta Program ‚Äì Be the First to Experience!

Business Value:

Your context-aware assistant for SAP Signavio screens. It explains what each screen does, highlights key data, and guides users through actions‚Äîmaking complex dashboards and models intuitive.

How to Access and Activate Agents

Getting Access to Agents:

To access agents in SAP Signavio, follow these steps:

1. Register yourself with the Influence Opportunity page. From this page, select Assessment Form and enter your details, including your Customer ID, the agents you wish to enable for your organization, your email address, and more.

Remember: The customers are selected for the beta program by SAP. Once you register for the program, we'll review your application and reach out for next steps, if you're selected.

What‚Äôs Next for Future Roadmap?
